title: When is the Dutch election 2017? Key dates, Netherlands election process explained

organizations.name: people’s party for freedom and democracy

text:
When is the Dutch election 2017? Key dates, Netherlands election process explained When is the Dutch election 2017? Key dates, Netherlands election process explained GEERT Wilders could cause Europe’s next political earthquake if his far-right party wins the Dutch election next Wednesday. PUBLISHED: 08:00, Fri, Mar 10, 2017 | UPDATED: 09:03, Fri, Mar 10, 2017 Getty Geert Wilders is going up against Prime Minister Mark Rutte in the Dutch general election 
The anti-Islam leader of the Dutch Party for Freedom (PVV) is leading in the polls ahead of the general election next week. 
As a wave of right-wing populism sweeps across Europe, here is what you need to know about the upcoming Dutch election. Related articles 
When is the Dutch election? 
The people of the Netherlands will go to the polls on Wednesday March 15 2017. Getty 
Will Geert Wilders win the Dutch election? 
Mr Wilders appears to be course to win the Dutch election after taking a clear in the polls over the past two months. 
The PVV leader looks likely to beat the current Prime Minister Mark Rutte from the centrist People’s Party for Freedom and Democracy (VVD). 
Support for the Labour Party (PvdA) has also collapsed after having governed in coalition with the VVD since 2012. 
There are about a dozen political parties taking part in the election due to the fragmented nature of Dutch politics. 
What happens if Geert Wilders wins the Dutch election? 
Even if Mr Wilders wins the Dutch election, he almost certainly will not become Prime Minister because he will struggle to form a coalition. 
Mr Rutte has said: “The chances that the VVD will rule with the PVV are zero. It is not going to happen.” 
The other Dutch parties are also unwilling to form a coalition with him, according to Rem Korteweg, a senior research fellow at the Centre for European Reform (CER). 
“I don’t expect Wilders to be in Government," Mr Korteweg said. 
"Neither do I think, in his heart of hearts, he wants to be in Government because it means that he will have to compromise.” Brexit aftershocks: Who's next to leave the EU? Wed, September 14, 2016 Britain has voted to leave the EU. So who's next? We look at which European countries want to hold their own EU referendum.
